message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The SCIP Optimization Suite 9.0
Paper Abstract: The SCIP Optimization Suite provides a collection of software packages for mathematical optimization, centered around the constraint integer programming (CIP) framework SCIP. This report discusses the enhancements and extensions included in the SCIP Optimization Suite 9.0. The updates in SCIP 9.0 include improved symmetry handling, additions and improvements of nonlinear handlers and primal heuristics, a new cut generator and two new cut selection schemes, a new branching rule, a new LP interface, and several bug fixes. The SCIP Optimization Suite 9.0 also features new Rust and C++ interfaces for SCIP, new Python interface for SoPlex, along with enhancements to existing interfaces. The SCIP Optimization Suite 9.0 also includes new and improved features in the LP solver SoPlex, the presolving library PaPILO, the parallel framework UG, the decomposition framework GCG, and the SCIP extension SCIP-SDP. These additions and enhancements have resulted in an overall performance improvement of SCIP in terms of solving time, number of nodes in the branch-and-bound tree, as well as the reliability of the solver.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the cutting plane method:

## Overview

In mathematical optimization, the cutting-plane method is any of a variety of optimization methods that iteratively refine a feasible set or objective function by means of linear inequalities, termed cuts.

## Applications

These procedures are commonly used to find integer solutions to mixed integer linear programming (MILP) problems, as well as to solve general, not necessarily differentiable convex optimization problems.(no content)Cutting-plane methods for general convex continuous optimization are known under various names such as Kelley's method and bundle methods, and are popularly used for non-differentiable convex minimization.

## History

The use of cutting planes to solve MILP was introduced by Ralph E. Gomory.(no content)Nowadays, all commercial MILP solvers use Gomory cuts in one way or another.

## Basic Approach

Cutting plane methods for MILP work by solving a non-integer linear program, the linear relaxation of the given integer program.

Links: [{"title":"Integer programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming"},{"title":"Constraint programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_programming"},{"title":"Constraint logic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_logic_programming"},{"title":"Constrained optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constrained_optimization"},{"title":"Quadratically constrained quadratic program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadratically_constrained_quadratic_program"},{"title":"Zuse Institute Berlin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zuse_Institute_Berlin"},{"title":"Linear programming relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_relaxation"},{"title":"OR-Tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OR-Tools"},{"title":"Constraint (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binding_constraint"},{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"}]

Based on the web search results, I can provide you with information about constraint integer programming:

## Overview

An integer programming problem is a mathematical optimization or feasibility program in which some or all of the variables are restricted to be integers. In many settings the term refers to integer linear programming (ILP), in which the objective function and the constraints (other than the integer constraints) are linear.

## Key Concepts

In mathematics, a constraint is a condition of an optimization problem that the solution must satisfy. There are several types of constraints—primarily equality constraints, inequality constraints, and integer constraints.(no content)If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem.

## Computational Complexity and Solution Methods

Integer programming is NP-complete. In particular, the special case of 0–1 integer linear programming, in which unknowns are binary, and only the restrictions must be satisfied, is one of Karp's 21 NP-complete problems.(no content)One class of algorithms are cutting plane methods, which work by solving the LP relaxation and then adding linear constraints that drive the solution towards being integer without excluding any integer feasible points.(no content)Another class of algorithms are variants of the branch and bound method. For example, the branch and cut method that combines both branch and bound and cutting plane methods.

## Applications and Tools

Google OR-Tools is a free and open-source software suite developed by Google for solving linear programming (LP), mixed integer programming (MIP), constraint programming (CP), vehicle routing (VRP), and related optimization problems.

I've completed the web search for "nonlinear optimization." Here's what I found:

## Overview

Nonlinear programming (NLP) is the process of solving an optimization problem where some of the constraints are not linear equalities or the objective function is not a linear function.(no content)It is the sub-field of mathematical optimization that deals with problems that are not linear.

## Solution Methods

Numerical methods for solving nonlinear optimization are iterative: they start with an initial point, and proceed to points that are supposed to be closer to the optimal point. There are three kinds of update rules: Zero-order routines which use only the values of the objective function and constraint functions; First-order routines which use also the values of the gradients of these functions; and Second-order routines which use also the values of the Hessians of these functions.

## Key Algorithms and Solvers

Several important approaches and tools exist for nonlinear optimization:

- Interior-point methods (also referred to as barrier methods) are algorithms for solving linear and non-linear convex optimization problems.
- The Gauss–Newton algorithm is used to solve non-linear least squares problems, which is equivalent to minimizing a sum of squared function values.
- IPOPT is a software library for large scale nonlinear optimization of continuous systems.

The search results show that nonlinear optimization is a rich field with many specialized algorithms and solvers designed for different types of problems and constraints.

Web search results for query: "branch and bound algorithm"

Links: [{"title":"Branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Branch and cut - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_cut"},{"title":"Branch and price - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_price"},{"title":"Joint compatibility branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_compatibility_branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Travelling salesman problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travelling_salesman_problem"},{"title":"Talk:Branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Talk:Uniform-cost search - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Uniform-cost_search"},{"title":"B* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B*"},{"title":"Shifting bottleneck heuristic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shifting_bottleneck_heuristic"}]

## Branch and Bound Algorithm

Branch-and-bound (BB, B&B, or BnB) is a method for solving optimization problems by breaking them down into smaller subproblems and using a bounding function to eliminate subproblems that cannot contain the optimal solution.(no content)It is an algorithm design paradigm for discrete and combinatorial optimization problems, as well as mathematical optimization.

### How It Works

A branch-and-bound algorithm consists of a systematic enumeration of candidate solutions by means of state-space search: the set of candidate solutions is thought of as forming a rooted tree with the full set at the root. The algorithm explores branches of this tree, which represent subsets of the solution set.(no content)Before enumerating the candidate solutions of a branch, the branch is checked against upper and lower estimated bounds on the optimal solution, and is discarded if it cannot produce a better solution than the best one found so far by the algorithm.(no content)To improve on the performance of brute-force search, a B&B algorithm keeps track of bounds on the minimum that it is trying to find, and uses these bounds to "prune" the search space, eliminating candidate solutions that it can prove will not contain an optimal solution.

### History

The method was first proposed by Ailsa Land and Alison Doig whilst carrying out research at the London School of Economics sponsored by British Petroleum in 1960 for discrete programming, and has become the most commonly used tool for solving NP-hard optimization problems.(no content)The name "branch and bound" first occurred in the work of Little et al. on the traveling salesman problem.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about heuristic optimization:

## Definition

Where finding an optimal solution is impossible or impractical, heuristic methods can be used to speed up the process of finding a satisfactory solution.(no content)A heuristic function ranks alternatives in search algorithms at each branching step based on available information to decide which branch to follow.

## Key Characteristics

Heuristics may produce results by themselves, or they may be used in conjunction with optimization algorithms to improve their efficiency.(no content)Results about NP-hardness in theoretical computer science make heuristics the only viable option for a variety of complex optimization problems that need to be routinely solved in real-world applications.

## Common Approaches

Several established heuristic methods are used in optimization:

- **Hill Climbing**: Hill climbing is a mathematical optimization technique which belongs to the family of local search, and is an iterative algorithm that starts with an arbitrary solution to a problem, then attempts to find a better solution by making an incremental change to the solution.

- **Local Search**: Local search is a heuristic method for solving computationally hard optimization problems.

- **Metaheuristics**: A metaheuristic is a higher-level procedure or heuristic designed to find, generate, tune, or select a heuristic that may provide a sufficiently good solution to an optimization problem.

## Limitations

Local search does not provide a guarantee that any given solution is optimal. However, local search is an anytime algorithm; it can return a valid solution even if it's interrupted at any time after finding the first valid solution.

Links: [{"title":"Integer programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_relaxation"},{"title":"Cutting-plane method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutting-plane_method"},{"title":"Mathematical optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_optimization"},{"title":"MINTO - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MINTO"},{"title":"Discrete optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_optimization"},{"title":"OR-Tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OR-Tools"},{"title":"Gérard Cornuéjols - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gérard_Cornuéjols"},{"title":"List of optimization software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_optimization_software"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about integer programming optimization:

## Definition and Overview

An integer programming problem is a mathematical optimization or feasibility program in which some or all of the variables are restricted to be integers.(no content)In many settings the term refers to integer linear programming (ILP), in which the objective function and the constraints (other than the integer constraints) are linear.

## Complexity

Integer programming is NP-complete (the difficult part is showing the NP membership).(no content)Integer programming studies linear programs in which some or all variables are constrained to take on integer values. This is not convex, and in general much more difficult than regular linear programming.

## Related Problem Types

If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem.

## Solution Methods

There are several approaches to solving integer programming problems:

1. **Cutting Plane Methods**: Cutting plane methods work by solving the LP relaxation and then adding linear constraints that drive the solution towards being integer without excluding any integer feasible points.

2. **Branch and Bound**: Another class of algorithms are variants of the branch and bound method.(no content)One advantage is that the algorithms can be terminated early and as long as at least one integral solution has been found, a feasible, although not necessarily optimal, solution can be returned. Further, the solutions of the LP relaxations can be used to provide a worst-case estimate of how far from optimality the returned solution is.

## Software Tools

Google OR-Tools is a free and open-source software suite developed by Google for solving linear programming (LP), mixed integer programming (MIP), constraint programming (CP), vehicle routing (VRP), and related optimization problems.

Links: [{"title":"Branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Branch and cut - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_cut"},{"title":"Branch and price - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_price"},{"title":"Edmonds' algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edmonds'_algorithm"},{"title":"Branching factor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branching_factor"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability algorithm heuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_algorithm_heuristics"},{"title":"Branch-decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch-decomposition"},{"title":"Branch predictor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_predictor"},{"title":"Branch (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Alpha–beta pruning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alpha–beta_pruning"}]

I found comprehensive information about branching algorithm optimization. Here are the key concepts:

## Overview of Branching Algorithms

Branch-and-bound (BB, B&B, or BnB) is a method for solving optimization problems by breaking them down into smaller subproblems and using a bounding function to eliminate subproblems that cannot contain the optimal solution. It is an algorithm design paradigm for discrete and combinatorial optimization problems, as well as mathematical optimization.

## Key Optimization Strategies

**Pruning and Bounds:** A B&B algorithm keeps track of bounds on the minimum that it is trying to find, and uses these bounds to "prune" the search space, eliminating candidate solutions that it can prove will not contain an optimal solution.

**Branching Factor:** Higher branching factors make algorithms that follow every branch at every node, such as exhaustive brute force searches, computationally more expensive due to the exponentially increasing number of nodes, leading to combinatorial explosion. The branching factor can be cut down by a pruning algorithm.

## Specialized Variants

- **Branch and Cut:** Branch and cut is a method of combinatorial optimization for solving integer linear programs (ILPs), that is, linear programming (LP) problems where some or all the unknowns are restricted to integer values. Branch and cut involves running a branch and bound algorithm and using cutting planes to tighten the linear programming relaxations.

- **Branch and Price:** Branch and price is a method of combinatorial optimization for solving integer linear programming (ILP) and mixed integer linear programming (MILP) problems with many variables. The method is a hybrid of branch and bound and column generation methods.

- **Alpha-Beta Pruning:** Alpha–beta pruning is a search algorithm that seeks to decrease the number of nodes that are evaluated by the minimax algorithm in its search tree. It is an adversarial search algorithm used commonly for machine playing of two-player combinatorial games.

Links: [{"title":"Branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Branch and cut - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_cut"},{"title":"Branch and price - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_price"},{"title":"Edmonds' algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edmonds'_algorithm"},{"title":"Branching factor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branching_factor"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability algorithm heuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_algorithm_heuristics"},{"title":"Branch-decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch-decomposition"},{"title":"Branch predictor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_predictor"},{"title":"Branch (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Alpha–beta pruning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alpha–beta_pruning"}]

I found comprehensive information about branching algorithm optimization. Here are the key concepts:

## Overview of Branching Algorithms

Branch-and-bound (BB, B&B, or BnB) is a method for solving optimization problems by breaking them down into smaller subproblems and using a bounding function to eliminate subproblems that cannot contain the optimal solution. It is an algorithm design paradigm for discrete and combinatorial optimization problems, as well as mathematical optimization.

## Key Optimization Strategies

**Pruning and Bounds:** A B&B algorithm keeps track of bounds on the minimum that it is trying to find, and uses these bounds to "prune" the search space, eliminating candidate solutions that it can prove will not contain an optimal solution.

**Branching Factor:** Higher branching factors make algorithms that follow every branch at every node, such as exhaustive brute force searches, computationally more expensive due to the exponentially increasing number of nodes, leading to combinatorial explosion. The branching factor can be cut down by a pruning algorithm.

## Specialized Variants

- **Branch and Cut:** Branch and cut is a method of combinatorial optimization for solving integer linear programs (ILPs), that is, linear programming (LP) problems where some or all the unknowns are restricted to integer values. Branch and cut involves running a branch and bound algorithm and using cutting planes to tighten the linear programming relaxations.

- **Branch and Price:** Branch and price is a method of combinatorial optimization for solving integer linear programming (ILP) and mixed integer linear programming (MILP) problems with many variables. The method is a hybrid of branch and bound and column generation methods.

- **Alpha-Beta Pruning:** Alpha–beta pruning is a search algorithm that seeks to decrease the number of nodes that are evaluated by the minimax algorithm in its search tree. It is an adversarial search algorithm used commonly for machine playing of two-player combinatorial games.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about linear programming solvers:

## Overview

Linear programming (LP), also called linear optimization, is a method to achieve the best outcome (such as maximum profit or lowest cost) in a mathematical model whose requirements and objective are represented by linear relationships.

## Popular Linear Programming Solvers

There are several types of linear programming solvers available:

**Open-Source Solvers:**

- GLOP (the Google Linear Optimization Package) is Google's open-source linear programming solver, created by Google's Operations Research Team.
- COIN-OR LP (CLP or Clp) is an open-source linear programming solver written in C++.
- The GNU Linear Programming Kit (GLPK) is a software package intended for solving large-scale linear programming (LP), mixed integer programming (MIP), and other related problems.

**Commercial Solvers:**

- Gurobi Optimizer is a solver for linear and quadratic programming with continuous or integer variables (MIP).
- The FICO Xpress optimizer is a commercial optimization solver for linear programming (LP), mixed integer linear programming (MILP), convex quadratic programming (QP), convex quadratically constrained quadratic programming (QCQP), second-order cone programming (SOCP) and their mixed integer variants.

**Modeling Languages:**

AMPL (A Mathematical Programming Language) is an algebraic modeling language to describe and solve high-complexity problems for large-scale mathematical computing (e.g. large-scale optimization and scheduling-type problems).

## Solution Methods

Dantzig's simplex algorithm (or simplex method) is an algorithm for linear programming.

I've completed a web search for "mathematical optimization." Here's an overview of the key information found:

## Definition and Overview

Mathematical optimization (alternatively spelled optimisation) or mathematical programming is the selection of a best element, with regard to some criteria, from some set of available alternatives. More specifically, mathematical optimization is the theory and computation of extrema or stationary points of functions.

## Main Categories

It is generally divided into two subfields: discrete optimization and continuous optimization.(no content)In discrete optimization, some or all of the variables used in a discrete optimization problem are restricted to be discrete variables—that is, to assume only a discrete set of values, such as the integers.

## Key Subfields

Combinatorial optimization is a subfield of mathematical optimization that consists of finding an optimal object from a finite set of objects, where the set of feasible solutions is discrete or can be reduced to a discrete set.(no content)Constrained optimization is the process of optimizing an objective function with respect to some variables in the presence of constraints on those variables.

## Historical Context

The term "linear programming" for certain optimization cases was due to George B. Dantzig, and Dantzig published the Simplex algorithm in 1947.

## Applications

Optimization deals with generating and selecting the best solution from some set of available alternatives, by systematically choosing input values from within an allowed set, computing the output of the function and recording the best output values found during the process. Many real-world problems can be modeled in this way.

I've completed the web search for "parallel algorithm computing". Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Parallel Algorithms: Key Concepts

**Definition**: A parallel algorithm is an algorithm which can do multiple operations in a given time, as opposed to a traditional serial algorithm.

**How It Works**: Parallel computing uses multiple processing elements simultaneously to solve a problem by breaking the problem into independent parts so that each processing element can execute its part of the algorithm simultaneously with the others.

**Key Challenges**:
- Parallel algorithms need to optimize communication between different processors.
- Communication and synchronization between the different subtasks are typically some of the greatest obstacles to getting optimal parallel program performance.
- Some problems cannot be split up into parallel portions as they require results from a preceding step; examples include iterative numerical methods such as Newton's method.

**Performance Considerations**: Until 2004, single-core processor performance rapidly increased, making multicore systems of limited use, but since 2004, frequency scaling hit a wall and multicore systems have become more widespread.

**Related Concepts**: Distributed algorithms are a sub-type of parallel algorithm, typically executed concurrently, with separate parts running simultaneously on independent processors.

Web search results for query: "graph decomposition algorithms"

Links: [{"title":"Cycle decomposition (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cycle_decomposition_(graph_theory)"},{"title":"Modular decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_decomposition"},{"title":"Tree decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_decomposition"},{"title":"Branch-decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch-decomposition"},{"title":"Category:Graph algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Graph_algorithms"},{"title":"Graph theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_theory"},{"title":"Split (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Split_(graph_theory)"},{"title":"Gallai–Edmonds decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gallai–Edmonds_decomposition"},{"title":"Decomposition method (constraint satisfaction) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decomposition_method_(constraint_satisfaction)"},{"title":"Graph (abstract data type) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_(data_structure)"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of graph decomposition algorithms:

## Main Types of Graph Decomposition

There are several important graph decomposition approaches:

### Cycle Decomposition
In graph theory, a cycle decomposition is a decomposition (a partitioning of a graph's edges) into cycles.(no content)The problem of decomposing an Eulerian graph into a minimum number of edge-disjoint cycles is NP-complete, as is the corresponding problem of decomposing into a maximum number of cycles.

### Modular Decomposition
In graph theory, the modular decomposition is a decomposition of a graph into subsets of vertices called modules.(no content)The first polynomial algorithm to compute the modular decomposition tree of a graph was published in 1972 and now linear algorithms are available.

### Tree Decomposition
In graph theory, a tree decomposition is a mapping of a graph into a tree that can be used to define the treewidth of the graph and speed up solving certain computational problems on the graph.(no content)They play an important role in problems like probabilistic inference, constraint satisfaction, query optimization, and matrix decomposition.

### Branch Decomposition
In graph theory, a branch-decomposition of an undirected graph G is a hierarchical clustering of the edges of G, represented by an unrooted binary tree T with the edges of G as its leaves. Removing any edge from T partitions the edges of G into two subgraphs, and the width of the decomposition is the maximum number of shared vertices of any pair of subgraphs formed in this way.

### Split Decomposition
The splits of a graph can be collected into a tree-like structure called the split decomposition or join decomposition, which can be constructed in linear time.

These decomposition algorithms are fundamental tools in graph theory with applications to optimization, pattern recognition, and solving various computational problems on graphs.

Links: [{"title":"Symmetry group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_group"},{"title":"Symmetric group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric_group"},{"title":"Group theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_theory"},{"title":"Molecular symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molecular_symmetry"},{"title":"Group (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Symmetry in mathematics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_in_mathematics"},{"title":"List of planar symmetry groups - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_planar_symmetry_groups"},{"title":"Symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry"},{"title":"Symmetry (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_(physics)"},{"title":"List of spherical symmetry groups - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_spherical_symmetry_groups"}]

Here are the search results for "symmetry group mathematics":

## Basic Definition

In group theory, the symmetry group of a geometric object is the group of all transformations under which the object is invariant, endowed with the group operation of composition. More broadly, a symmetry group may be any kind of transformation group, or automorphism group.

## Key Concepts

Symmetry is a type of invariance: the property that a mathematical object remains unchanged under a set of operations or transformations.(no content)Conceptually, group theory can be thought of as the study of symmetry.

## Examples and Types

There are several types of symmetry groups:

- **Continuous Symmetry Groups**: There are continuous symmetry groups (Lie groups), which contain rotations of arbitrarily small angles or translations of arbitrarily small distances. For example, O(3) is the symmetry group of a sphere.

- **Discrete Symmetry Groups**: D3, D4 etc. are the symmetry groups of the regular polygons.

- **Point Groups**: There are five fundamental symmetry classes which have triangular fundamental domains: dihedral, cyclic, tetrahedral, octahedral, and icosahedral symmetry.

## Historical Development

Évariste Galois, in the 1830s, introduced the term group (French: groupe) for the symmetry group of the roots of an equation, now called a Galois group.

## Applications

Symmetry groups have important applications across mathematics and physics, from understanding geometric transformations to analyzing the properties of physical systems.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity, entity_type: one of task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results, relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
